text: Patient: What kind of breathing machine? Doctor: Uh. A ventilator. On TV. Those are television. Your body’s gotten so sick that if I get you to wake up, you still have the bad cancer. Patient: Oh. Doctor: Okay? So, I also, I mean, I’m not so sure we should be pounding on your chest. Uh, you should be thinking about how far will we go even if it looks bad. (Pause) Patient: No. See, my dad died from prostate cancer in nineteen eighty six. He hadn’t -- didn’t have much treatment at all. Uh. Family Member: He waited, he waited to have severe symptoms. Then he went and then (they’s found) Patient: So, um, you know, I’m concerned for my son. My brother. Uh. He might have something too. I mean, if I try somethin’, it will help ‘em. Doctor: Yeah. I mean, so this may not help you, but it may help us learn how to treat other men in the future. Uh. So, that is, you know, just you being a good citizen and helping that out and a hero, but that – you have to feel comfortable with that, you know, ‘cuz it could help. It may not help. If it does help, it may help others. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um. And yet it’s your time. It’s your coming in here. Some of it’s your expense. You know, this drug enzalutamide, I don’t know what you were paying when you were on it before. Uh. It’s pretty expensive. It’s about ten thousand bucks a month. Um. And again, you would be taking it, even though we don’t think it’s gonna work ‘cuz -- because we think that it may make the immune therapy work better. So, we have to have people on it. Their PSA’s gonna be rising. Their ARV seven still has to be positive. (Laughs) Patient: Okay. I didn’t pay much for the Xtandi before. Uh, some kind of study from manufacturers – Doctor: Oh, so you had a study, or they had a, uh, a program that sort of reduced your cost?

text: Family Member: There’s a halo around you that you don’t see, but we do. That’s why we’re here. Doctor: Well thank you. Family Member: Seriously. Family Member: Because you care, that she listens. Doctor: But and I have also have some donor money Family Member: Okay. Doctor: If you know, for medical expenses Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: if it’s getting to be too much let me know, bring it in, and then we’ll consider that. Okay? Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Alright Family Member: We appreciate you. Thank you for your input.

text: Healthcare Professional: Um hum. Doctor: - depending on. And then um in point six percent of people you could get a seizure. I point that out out of all the list because that’s to me the most scary - Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: - if it were me. But you know point six is less – Family Member: Right. Doctor: - than one as in we give this stuff all the time and people, knock on wood - Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: - have not had it as an issue. Family Member: Everybody has their issues. Doctor: It is. text: Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know that’s an early phase—Phase I study. That clearly has no data as to whether it works. And so you could window it in at this point, but if the scans when we get them show that the stuff that’s in your liver is even big in other areas, Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: you know whether or not you have the willingness or sort of the time to sort of participate in something that’s you know experimental of that nature of a brand new drug is questionable. But some people clearly want to avoid chemotherapy at all costs and are willing to try that even if you know it doesn’t work and they were to miss that opportunity for chemotherapy. So everybody sort of chooses based on who they talk to, who their neighbors are, who’s been through chemo. Doctor: What they are willing to think about. Patient: Yes, I have the time. Yeah. Doctor: Time is one thing, but again you know what the cancer is going to do is the other. Patient: Side effects and all that, yeah, I don’t know what, yeah. Doctor: So those would be potentially three options. If we’re going to go chemotherapy, whether we add in the Vitamin C or not; you get the infusion, you don’t know whether it’s the real thing or Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: you get the real chemo. The other one is the immune therapy which my reservation at this point is the gasping thing. Family Member: Mm, hmm.

text: Family Member: Right. Doctor: But I also would prefer the two of you be the voice, you know. ‘Cuz for me to go over it four different times just because -- Family Member: Right. Doctor: Someone’s not able to get here makes it difficult. Family Member: Right. Patient: Well she has court today. Her ex-husband is – Family Member: Being a pain in the ass. Patient: He wants more custody of the kids. So, she has her own mess. Doctor: I get it. Well, what we would be doing is we’d be seeing a lot of you. So, again, some of those visits she – you know, hopefully, the court stuff is better that she can come down with you. Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Um. So, does that make sense to try that and go that route? I mean, or is it really you want to think about it more – uh, step back and again talk to your doctor about the chemo again? Do you want to get his opinion or her opinion about the trial? Um. Patient: I think the, the trial’s a little more targeted. The chemo is more general.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you are no longer benefiting but the idea is that I want to go to chemotherapy on its own or as part of the study vis a vis switching to this. Patient: How long would the chemotherapy? How long would that last? Doctor: Okay, so the chemotherapy, we tend to give ten cycles if it’s benefiting you. They’re given once every three weeks. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Or if it’s not benefiting you, we usually know by the third or fourth cycle that your PSA is rising and you don’t tolerate it so we have to make some changes. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? So when the numbers change, it’s consent forms. Patient: Yeah, yeah, put that right Doctor: So that’s your homework. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay, and then I will send Dr. G an email tomorrow and make sure he sees what I’m thinking,

text: Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know, and is that just a swollen gland from inflammation that’s coming there. Cancer really shouldn’t give you a gland. You know, unless that gland is involved. Um, but that’s where the normal prostate cancer goes. It goes to the bone. Patient: Right. Doctor: So, I can’t, I’m not judging. I don’t know what that is. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Your CAT scan, uh, says that there’s more, uh, there’s more scarring at the bone sites. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: So, that’s why they can see scarring on CAT scans, but that’s just again, inflammation. Um. And they love to use . And then, the only change that we see is in your right adrenal gland. Patient: MM, hmm. Doctor: And they’re saying there’s a nodular appearance, and there’s inflammation around it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, so, they don’t know what it is. I went up there. That’s why I wasn’t in right when you got here ‘cuz I wanted to go over it with the radiologist. Like, can you tell me what you think it is, and they don’t know. They’re hedging. Okay? Patient: Okay.

text: Family Member: Yeah. Yeah. They were dealing with somebody that was off, a robber or something. Patient: Okay. Well that didn’t affect our drive. Doctor: No. But I’m sure with the game. text: Patient: Yes. Doctor: It sounds like we’re going to keep you on the study for now. In order to do so, we have to stop the medication to allow this anemia to recover. Hopefully, it will. Uh, so as of today, uh, no more Patient: Okay. Doctor: Until you come back and see us on September the fifth. Uh, L___ will be in touch with you after she comes back. Family Member: She’ll be here tomorrow. Doctor: She actually had to leave unexpectedly because her house had some flooding which she had to take care of, which is why she’s not here. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But, uh, we will schedule the, uh, complete blood count which includes hemoglobin for next Monday, Tuesday, or Wednesday, the early part of next week. Based on that, I will make a decision about whether a transfusion will be necessary or not. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: If the transfusion is necessary, we’ll also do that through the K___ system. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And we will have all that completed before September fifth. So that when you come back, we’ll give you the best possible chance to start the medication again, albeit at a lower dose, because it’ll be the two-hundred milligram dose.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
